posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
Hello, all! Some of you are aware that we’ve been working on a pretty cool device-independent backup format, and now we’re looking to test our first use-case: syncing your message history with a newly-linked device! You heard that right – your newly-linked devices will finally have all of your message history

I think this is something we’ve all wanted for a while, so it’s really cool to finally build it. But building something like this is very tricky, and testing it tends to uncover lots of weird bugs, many of which are specific to each individual’s message history.

So, we come to you, dear forum users, to ask for your help testing this before we go to a wider beta. Similar to how we did early tests with usernames, we’re going to have a little advanced testing program.

Thankfully, participating in this test should be a bit easier than the username one! First off, you simply need to be running Android 7.28+ or iOS 7.42+. The normal beta releases are fine! But you will need a special version of desktop, which you can get here:

  • Windows
  • Mac
  • Linux

This special version of desktop has a few key characteristics:

  1. It communicates to your primary that it’s capable of link+syncing, allowing you to test the feature.
  2. It’s considered a totally separate app from the normal beta/prod desktop releases, with separate storage, so you can test it without having to reset your normal desktop instance!
  3. It does not auto-update – this isn’t meant to be used long-term!

We hope this lets you test and re-test as much as you’d like, without the fear of losing any data

You can also test using an iPad running 7.42+, which you can access using the normal beta channel.

One thing to note: when using the backup format in this situation, we do not include media. The only media that syncs is media that was sent/received in the last 45 days, because that’s how long encrypted media lives on Signal’s servers in order to match the current maximum timeframe for queued messages for offline devices. Media older that that will not be available.

Thank you in advance! I’m always grateful for our many dedicated forum users, and I hope ya’ll have fun testing this out and reporting bugs :)

What types of bugs to report

Anything and everything related to the linking process! There are very few “known issues” on our side, but I suspect you will all still find plenty :) In particular, please keep an eye out for:

  • Any errors that occur during linking
  • Any mismatch in content between your android and desktop devices after linking
  • Any performance issues (syncing taking longer than 30-60 sec)

If you encounter any problems, please post here, and include debuglogs from both devices.

Please also share any other feedback you have around the general UX!

The only thing we request that you don’t report is general Android/desktop bugs that are unrelated to the initial syncing of messages – please submit those bugs to either GitHub or the beta threads.

FAQ

Is this safe?
Yes! Everything is end-to-end encrypted at all times. The data sent over to your desktop is encrypted with a strong, single-use 256-bit key that only your linked device has access to. That key is sent over the same pre-existing encrypted channel where we share other crucial keys with the linked device already. Which is to say, if you feel comfortable with the way we link devices today, you can continue to feel comfortable with this new addition.

Where’s all of my older media?
As noted above, we can only sync media sent/received in the last 45 days.

What if I don’t want to sync my message history to my newly-linked device?
You don’t have to! You can choose whether or not you want to sync your messages during the linking process.

What if everything works fine?
Still post a log! They’re useful to get a sense of performance numbers, and logs could indicate non-fatal-but-still-bad things that happened during the backup/import.

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
anon53652:

This brought back all the groups I removed when the stalker was active

Can you share more about the groups? Were blocked from your perspective, or just left+deleted?

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
Well the spamming got so bad at the time (dozens of groups each day) that I implemented an auto-leave in my Signal fork. I didn’t block them to prevent my blocklist from exploding.

At least I didn’t see them anymore on Android, but they seem to be still there.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Everything seemed to have worked great the first time around. Thank you!!
It did take about 30-60 seconds for the backup to start restoring, but it wasn’t too bad at all.

I did notice that I have a bunch of random empty chats in my conversation list on desktop. These are probably people I was in a group with at one point, but I don’t recognize any of them. There are probably about 50 chats there.

image561×1181 46.4 KB

Everything below the red line is a random empty chat with someone I’ve never had a conversation with.

Android logs: https://debuglogs.org/android/7.28.0/de376bd2c888f2e10bc4c01e43ccb3199d7041cebca0c06e8e5ba4f8f5e84fb3
Desktop logs: https://debuglogs.org/desktop/7.39.0-adhoc.20241213.16-a970d647c/a6b8ec221fca470faa122844e9cf246a33ee53ab63e954e155b30d81408130bb.gz

I did also notice that immediately after the transfer was complete and I was brought to the conversation list, none of the nicknames/contact names I had set loaded right away. It took several minutes for them to load in.

greyson-signal:

when using the backup format in this situation, we do not include media. The only media that syncs is media that was sent/received in the last 45 days

Does this imply that text-messages older than 45 days are stored on the server? If not how do they get transferred? In other words does every bit of history transfer need to go through the server, or is there some p2p mechanism involved?

*Just clarifying

Conversation list got populated with many contacts I’ve never had 1:1 conversation but we share(d) group chats.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: i would imagine that what happens is that text, being much lighter than media, is transferred directly, while media is transferred as pointer to access the encrypted media cached on the server.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked: A little UX thing: I just recognized that I’m not asked how the new device should be called if I select to sync history. The new device is automatically named “Linux”. If I select to not sync my history to the desktop, I’m asked for the device name.

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 7.32 release

posts.cooked:
Hey, Gresyon. Excellent work as always, it’s actually wonderful you guys pulled this off!

I’m not sure if the following is a design choice or something you’ll implement later, but I’ve been jumping around the Android code and the backup proto file and couldn’t find where you guys backup an account’s own identity keypair. I know that they’re synced to linked devices and thus are not needed to be included in the ephemeral backup, but in the future this backup system will replace the legacy (current) one afaik.

The legacy (current) Android backup system always backed up own account’s both ACI and PNI keypair.

Why does it matter? Well, I never worried about my contacts getting safety number change warnings just because I restored from a backup, but with the new system, they’ll be getting those warnings which I really don’t want because I actually do verify these safety numbers in person.

Again, I totally understand that it doesn’t matter in the link+sync case, but in the future when we backup and restore using the new system, it will matter.

I even tried looking around the storage service system that backs up and restores automatically when we enter he pin and you guys don’t backup the keys there either.

Ps. Sorry in advance if it’s just me who couldn’t find the code that backs up the keypair.

This worked very well!

The message transfer took less than a minute, and everything including recent media is there.
A pleasant surprise is this also synced the chat colours from my phone.

Like @DirkPitt1 I too now have a gazillion Signal contacts in the new desktop app conversations list, most of which contacts I believed I had deleted (they are from groups I was in, but never chatted 1:1 with any of them).

Desktop debug log:

https://debuglogs.org/desktop/7.39.0-adhoc.20241213.16-a970d647c/c1641b4284c631998f6ac5a7dc045daf9e6b7c00d67595f6a09475bd47e32dd2.gz

Phone debug log:

https://debuglogs.org/android/7.28.0/b3a87b5fadfb5a58bc21ce3dea25565b54f1a1437249b32e9b432c46030e19f1

posts.name: Xashyar
posts.cooked:
rassilon1963:

text, being much lighter than media, is transferred directly

And by direct you mean device-to-device transfer without server mediation?

fancy_title: Help us test desktop history syncing!
title: Help us test desktop history syncing!

accepted_answer.name: Greyson Parrelli
accepted_answer.excerpt:
Hello all! Wanted to announce that we are taking this feature to the wider public beta! Thank you all so much for all of the time and effort you’ve put into testing this feature. It’s helped us find plenty of bugs that we otherwise would not have found. We’re incredibly grateful for all of the time you’ve volunteered to help make Signal better for everyone.

We’ll probably post one more desktop build here to allow people to test without having to reset their beta instance, but otherwise testing in this thread is complete! Please direct all bug reports to the respective beta threads.

Thank you!
